children.text: Content Standard 1: Students shall demonstrate knowledge of art from the Baroque and Rococo periods.
Identify characteristics of art and terminology related to art produced during the Baroque and Rococo periods (e.g., European)

Identify Baroque and Rococo artists, artwork, and architecture (e.g., Borromini, Van Dyck, Rembrandt, Caravaggio, , Gainsborough, Vermeer, Bernini, architecture of Versailles, the David, the Conversion of St. Paul)

Recognize various influences on and/or connections to Baroque and Rococo art and design (e.g., social, cultural, geographical, environmental, political, spiritual, economical, technological, architectural, literature, music, performing arts)
Identify the impact of Baroque and Rococo art and design on that society and future societies
Identify media and processes found in Baroque and Rococo artwork
Identify themes that appear in Baroque and Rococo artwork (e.g., universal, societal, individual)

Identify master artists and major artworks during this time period from the United States (e.g., Benjamin West, John S. Copley, metalsmithing, crafts) and other global cultures (e.g., Asia, Africa, Pacific, the Americas)
Analyze Baroque and Rococo artwork and design (e.g., creative intentions, styles, symbols, purposes for creating)
Content Standard 2: Students shall demonstrate knowledge of art from the Pre-Modern era.

Identify characteristics of art and terminology related to art produced during the Pre-Modern era (e.g., Neoclassicism, Romanticism, American landscape painting movement, Realism, Barbizon, Impressionism)

Identify European artists, artworks, and architecture from the Pre-Modern era (e.g., Houdon, Gericault, Manet, Monet, J., Rodin, Renoir, Degas, M. W. Turner, the Houses of Parliament, the Raft of the Medusa, the Luncheon on the Grass)

Identify master artists and major works from the United States during the Pre-Modern era (e.g., Thomas Cole, Henry Tanner, Robert Duncanson, Edmonia Lewis, Joshua Johnson, Mary Cassatt, Winslow Homer, Monticello, Kindred Spirits by Asher B. Durand)
Identify artists, architecture, and artworks from other global cultures during this time period (e.g., Asia, Africa, Pacific, the Americas)

Recognize various influences on and/or connections to Pre-Modern art and design (e.g., social, cultural, geographical, environmental, political, spiritual, economical, technological, architectural, literature, music, performing arts)
Identify the impact of Pre-Modern art and design on existing and future societies
Identify media and processes found in Pre-Modern artwork
Identify themes that appear in Pre-Modern artwork (e.g., universal, societal, individual)
Analyze Pre-Modern artwork and design (e.g., creative intentions, styles, symbols, purposes for creating)
Content Standard 3: Students shall demonstrate knowledge of art from the Modern era.

Identify characteristics of art and terminology related to art produced during the Modern era (e.g., Post-Impressionism, Pointillism, Expressionism, Fauvism, Cubism, Dada, Bauhaus, Harlem Renaissance, Futurism, Surrealism, International Style, Constructivism)

Identify European artists, artworks, and architecture, from the Modern era (e.g., Matisse, Vincent van Gogh, Edvard Munch, Gauguin, Delaunay, Itten, Albers, Malevich, Boccioni, Kollwitz, Picasso, Jean Arp, Henry Moore, Kandinsky, Starry Night, The Scream, The Bauhaus)

Identify movements, master artists, and major works from the United States during the Modern era (e.g., Frederic Remington, Charles Russell, James Audubon, Edward Hopper, Georgia O'Keeffe, Alfred Stieglitz, Jacob Lawrence, Louis Sullivan, Romare Bearden, Elizabeth Catlett)
Identify artists, architecture, and artworks from other global cultures during this time period (e.g., Asia, Africa, Pacific, the Americas)

Recognize various influences on and/or connections to Modern art and design (e.g., social, cultural, geographical, environmental, political, spiritual, economical, technological, architectural, literature, music, performing arts)
Identify the impact of Modern art and design on existing and future societies
Identify media and processes found in Modern artwork
Identify themes that appear in Modern artwork (e.g., universal, societal, individual)
Analyze Modern artwork and design (e.g., creative intentions, styles, symbols, purposes for creating)
Content Standard 4: Students shall demonstrate knowledge of art from the Post-Modern era.

Identify characteristics of art and terminology related to art produced during the Post-Modern era (e.g., Abstract Expressionism, Op Art, Pop Art, Photo-Realism/Superrealism, Minimalism, Color Field Painting, Post-Modernism, New Realism, Conceptual Art, Performance Art, Neo-Expressionism, Media Arts, Post-Modern Classicism, Installation Art, Environmental Art, Feminist Art, Graffiti, Outsider Art, Visual Culture)
Identify global artists, artworks, and architecture of the Post-Modern era (e.g., United States, Europe, Asia, Africa, Pacific, the Americas)

Recognize various influences on and/or connections to art and design of the Post-Modern era (e.g., social, cultural, geographical, environmental, political, spiritual, economical, technological, architectural, literature, music, performing arts)
Identify the impact of Post-Modern art and design on current societies and predict the impact on future movements
Identify media and processes found in Post-Modern artwork
Identify themes that appear in Post-Modern artwork (e.g., universal, societal, individual)
Analyze Post-Modern artwork and design (e.g., creative intentions, styles, symbols, purposes for creating)
